policy_name: AI Tools in Academic Work: Berkeley Student Guide
introduction: UC Berkeley recognizes that generative AI tools (ChatGPT, Claude, GitHub Copilot, etc.) are becoming prevalent in education and research. This guide provides a framework for responsible, ethical use of AI while maintaining academic integrity and authentic learning.
core_values: Academic Integrity: Your work must represent your genuine understanding
Transparency: Disclose AI use clearly and completely
Learning Objectives: AI should enhance, not replace, your education
Critical Thinking: You must evaluate AI outputs with skepticism and verification

allowed_uses.description: Using AI to explore ideas, generate questions, and develop approaches
examples: Using ChatGPT to brainstorm research topics
Using AI to generate hypotheses and test approaches
Using AI to explore different problem-solving strategies
allowed_uses.disclosure: Not required for private exploration; recommend in formal work

allowed_uses.description: Using AI as a tutor to understand difficult material
examples: Using ChatGPT to explain quantum mechanics
Using AI to work through practice problems
Using AI to see alternative explanations
allowed_uses.disclosure: Not required for learning; acknowledge if included in assessments

allowed_uses.description: Using AI to find, organize, and summarize research materials
examples: Using AI to organize bibliography and find related work
Using AI to summarize journal articles
Using AI to identify research gaps and opportunities
allowed_uses.disclosure: Required in formal research papers and theses

allowed_uses.description: Using AI for editing, organization, and clarity improvements
allowed_uses.when_allowed: All written work with appropriate disclosure
examples: Using Grammarly or similar for proofreading
Using AI to improve organization and flow
Using AI to clarify complex explanations

allowed_uses.when_allowed: Computer Science and related courses with disclosure
examples: Using GitHub Copilot to generate code segments
Using AI to understand programming concepts
Using AI to debug errors
allowed_uses.disclosure: Required with detailed comments in code

allowed_uses.description: Using AI to analyze data, create visualizations, and interpret results
allowed_uses.when_allowed: Research and advanced coursework with disclosure
examples: Using AI to suggest statistical methods
Using AI to generate publication-quality visualizations
Using AI to check calculations and verify results
allowed_uses.disclosure: Required in methods section and reproducibility statement

prohibited_uses.why_prohibited: Violates academic honesty; misrepresents your abilities
examples: Submitting ChatGPT-written essay without disclosure
Turning in AI-generated code as your own
Presenting AI analysis as your original thinking
prohibited_uses.penalty: Academic misconduct charge, possible course failure or suspension

prohibited_uses.why_prohibited: Undermines learning objectives when instructor restricts AI
examples: Using AI on exam marked 'no electronic aids'
Using AI on 'individual work only' assignment
Using AI to complete work you're meant to learn yourself
prohibited_uses.penalty: Failing grade on assignment or course

examples: Using AI to generate fake experimental data
Creating non-existent citations
Generating false quotations from authors

prohibited_uses.prohibition: Presenting AI Understanding as Your Own
prohibited_uses.why_prohibited: Circumvents skill development required by course
examples: Submitting AI-written code you don't understand
Using AI to bypass core learning competencies
Relying entirely on AI without personal learning

format_options.template: AI Disclosure: [Tool] was used to [specific task]. The output was [describe modifications/verification].
AI Tools Used in This Work: [List tools, purposes, extent of use, and verification done]
# This [function/section] was generated using [tool] on [date] and has been [verified/modified as follows]
Data analysis was conducted using [software] with AI assistance from [tool]. All results were independently verified using [verification method].

what_to_include: Name and version of AI tool(s) used
Specific purpose (brainstorming, code generation, proofreading, etc.)
How much of the work involved AI (entire document, specific sections, iterative use, etc.)
What you did with AI output (use as-is, modify substantially, verify, etc.)
Any limitations or concerns about AI output

syllabus_recommendations: State your policy on AI use clearly (permitted, prohibited, or case-by-case)
Explain how policy varies by assignment type
Provide specific disclosure requirements and examples
in_class_discussion: Discuss capabilities and limitations of AI tools
Share examples of appropriate and inappropriate use
assessment_strategies: Use varied assessment methods (not just essays vulnerable to AI)
Include components requiring demonstration of understanding (viva voce, presentations)
Require explanations of methodology and reasoning
Use plagiarism/AI detection tools as supporting evidence only
identifying_concerns: Unexpected improvement in quality beyond demonstrated ability
Generic phrasing inconsistent with student's voice
Content beyond evident understanding in class
responding_to_suspected_misuse: Interview student non-accusingly about their work process
Ask to explain methodology and reasoning
Request viva voce examination if appropriate

discipline_specific_considerations.guidance: Emphasis on understanding and verification. AI code generation acceptable with understanding verification. All calculations must be verified.
Original analysis is paramount. AI can assist with research organization. AI-generated content should be minimal. Critical thinking must be clearly evident.
Different rules may apply for clinical/professional practice. Verify requirements with program director. Competency demonstration is essential.
AI-assisted work is evolving field. Discuss with instructor. Attribution of AI collaboration expected. Creative intent and execution still required from student.

academic_misconduct_procedure.reporting: Contact UC Berkeley Office of Student Conduct
academic_misconduct_procedure.appeals: Appeals process available per Academic Integrity Policy
academic_misconduct_procedure.resources: Student support and counseling available throughout process

frequently_asked_questions.q: Can I use ChatGPT to write my paper?
frequently_asked_questions.a: No. You can use AI for brainstorming, organization, and proofreading. You must write the main analysis and arguments yourself. Disclose any substantial AI use.

frequently_asked_questions.q: Is GitHub Copilot allowed for programming assignments?
frequently_asked_questions.a: Generally yes with disclosure, but check your instructor's specific policy. You must understand and be able to explain all code you submit. Verify it works correctly.

frequently_asked_questions.q: What if my instructor says nothing about AI use?
frequently_asked_questions.a: Ask your instructor directly about their expectations. When in doubt, disclose your AI use. Transparency is better than concealment.

frequently_asked_questions.q: Can I use AI tools during exams?
frequently_asked_questions.a: No, unless explicitly permitted by your instructor. Exams typically require individual effort without electronic aids.
